awd_titl_txt: Collaborative Research: Physiologically Based Optimization of ICU Management
awd_abstract_narration:
An Intensive Care Unit (ICU) is an important and expensive resource. Modeling patient flow through an ICU is challenging because it requires a stochastic and dynamic model of patient physiology  Under the auspices of this award, the investigators will use a detailed data set to build a stochastic and dynamic model of patient physiology with the objective of improving ICU discharge predictions and subsequent flow through the hospital. This is achieved through three tasks: 1) creating a dynamic Transfer Readiness Score and a stochastic model of patient length of stay (LOS) based on patient physiology and transfer delay dynamics; 2) developing an optimization model to make anticipative bed requests using the created dynamic and stochastic score; 3) investigating the routing control problems between the ICUs and downstream units by developing new "score-based" queueing and stochastic network models. The PIs will recruit under-represented undergraduate and graduate students to this project. 

The intellectual merit of this project lies in the integration of stochastic and dynamic models of physiology with patient flow management to improve patient outcomes as well as operational efficiency. These tasks will require customization of stochastic modeling and optimization techniques. Task I will introduce a physiologically based stochastic and dynamic transfer readiness score that considers physiology as well as blocking delays. Task II will develop an anticipative bed request scheme to optimize patient transitions from ICUs to the downstream units as well as patient outcomes. Approximation techniques and optimality bounds will be developed for the problem. Task III will create score-based queueing and stochastic network models in which the service distribution is a function of an exogenous stochastic process (patient physiology), thus capturing the high variability of LOS in the ICUs. Score-based routing control policies and algorithms will be developed, where routing decisions are made for patients in treatment (jobs in service) rather than in queue. In addition, a decentralized network optimization will be studied in the context. These models will be used to determine ICU capacity decisions through a two-stage stochastic program, in which the recourse problem captures the underlying queueing network.

por.por_cntn:
An Intensive Care Unit (ICU) is an important and expensive resource within a hospital. Modeling patient flow through an ICU is challenging because, unlike other patient flow models, capturing the complexities of patient physiology is crucial. Developing such a model requires enormous volumes of highly detailed data. Using a better data set than any described in the literature, this project seeks a better understanding of patient physiology that can significantly improve ICU operations and predictions. 

We have developed a transfer readiness score model to predict when a patient is ready to be transferred to a downstream unit, which takes into account readmission and mortality risk. Using a large data set, we have performed extensive numerical studies comparing our novel anticipative (i.e., proactive) transfer model to the current practice of reactive transfers. Our results indicate that the mean transfer delay can be reduced by almost 50%. This reduction may significantly improve the system performance. Using machine learning models, we have further created a readmission and post-discharge mortality model which is richer and performs better than the existing models in the literature. This model can be used to benchmark ICU discharge policies and guide post-ICU resource needs.

Based on the transfer readiness score process, we have developed a multi-period model and approximation solutions. Numerical studies showed that the approximation algorithm performs well relative to the exact approach. Further comparing our approach to various heuristic policies, we demonstrated the superiority of the approximation algorithm for real-life instances. The results show that proactive strategies perform better than current practice in most of the settings, with the exception of cases where the downstream unit cost is extremely underestimated. This shows that anticipative policies can be safely used in practice.

We have also developed an ICU-­downstream network model with which to guide the transfer allocation of ICU patients discharged to downstream units as well as the flexible staffing of downstream unit beds. Our model seeks to streamline the transfer process by ensuring beds are staffed and available when needed and incoming ICU patients are not diverted due to transfer delays. Based on the dynamic multi-period model, we have derived acuity-based policies for the flexible staffing of downstream beds and allocation of ICU patients to downstream beds. These policies provide simple and easy-to-implement rules that can guide daily operational decisions. Furthermore, our analysis is applicable to various networks and captures complex system dynamics and unit interactions in making daily decisions. The large-scale numerical studies we performed using a 26-week simulation calibrated with historic hospital data demonstrated that the acuity-based policies outperform existing policies in the literature in reducing the number of diverted ICU admissions. These results are significant for improving ICU patient throughput and ensuring some of the most critically ill patients receive timely care.

To account for the highly dynamic nature in the ICU length of stay, we have studied new queueing models with time-varying service times and developed new methods using the method of chaining to validate the model by proving functional limit theorems. The models provide better approximations for the congestion and delays experienced by ICU patients than those with a fixed distribution. We also have studied scheduling and routing control problems in parallel server networks that may be used for the transfer of patients from ICUs to downstream units.
